data.title: 100 Best Postmodernism Books of All Time (Updated for 2021)
data.meta_description: The worldâs best postmodernism books of all time. Recommended by leading experts like Barack Obama, Oprah Winfrey, and Richard Branson.
data.text:
Carlos EireEven though he is no philosopher Vonnegut is still able to ask the questions that all of us think about â how time affects our lives. (Source)

Bernard TanIâm also a Murakami and Vonnegut fan, Kafka on the Shore, The Wind-up Bird Chronicle, Norwegian Wood, Slaughterhouse-Five, etc. Now that I look at the books listed, they seem to carry an existential theme. I guess I like to understand humanity and human behaviour ultimately to better understand myself. I find reading a means to connect with people who may have lived before my time, or in a... (Source)

Richard CohenItâs more imbued with references to the sun and using the sun as symbol or metaphor â almost a kind of character in the novel â than any other work in literature. (Source)

Bryan CallenSo here are my three must read books. I've been reading a lot of great books like: Outsmart Your Instincts, The Culture Code, and Antonio Damasioâs The Strange Order, and sometimes when you read a lot of nonfiction itâs very enriching, sometimes you need a novel. I really believe you should take a minute and read something beautiful. Listen, listen to Lolita by Nabokov. But also listen to Blood... (Source)

Chad HarbachI think Infinite Jest is the major American novel of the past 25 yearsâ¦Itâs the book on which his reputation will rest, and I think people are going to read it for a long time. (Source)

Rebecca GoldsteinItâs an extraordinary bookâ¦One of the things that he is examining in the novel is the various games that we play, many of them recursive. (Source)

Mark BittmanI used to buy [this book] for a lot of people because I just thought if you hadnât read it, you had to but maybe that era is over. (Source)

Barack ObamaWhen asked what books he recommended to his 18-year-old daughter Malia, Obama gave the Times a list that included The Naked and the Dead and One Hundred Years of Solitude. âI think some of them were sort of the usual suspects [â¦] I think she hadnât read yet. Then there were some books that are not on everybodyâs reading list these days, but I remembered as being interesting.â Hereâs what he... (Source)

Richard BransonToday is World Book Day, a wonderful opportunity to address this #ChallengeRichard sent in by Mike Gonzalez of New Jersey: Make a list of your top 65 books to read in a lifetime. (Source)

Andy SternI think it's something that progressives need to think about, because the book talks a lot about two tendencies that people can adopt, to try to find meaning and purpose. One is kind of a sheer technological approach, and the other is more of a spiritual and religious approach. The book talks about the perils and challenges of each way. Sometimes we as progressives defend technology and science... (Source)

Vanora BennettI read this a few years ago and it was one of those books you always remember because it creates a whole new way of thinking. I had no idea at the time that the medieval mindset was any different to the modern one. It is about the adventure of a Franciscan friar and his novice in medieval Italy and it is part murder mystery, part game with semiotics and medieval knowledge. At university I read... (Source)

Amelia BooneThis is a book that you have to hold, because there are parts of it where you need to turn it upside down to read it. There are certain pages where, you are reading it, and it turns in a circle... This is a book that's an entire sensory experience. (Source)

Colin ThubronOh God. Well, officially itâs Marco Polo describing the cities of his travels to Kublai Khan. Itâs been opined that every city he describes is a version of Venice, but I think that doesnât really work. They seem to me to be marvellous imaginative fantasies, which sometimes reproduce states of mind. There are 40 or so cities described, all entirely imaginary I think, and thatâs whatâs so magical... (Source)

James MeekIt has different layers. The set-up is that Kublai Khan has conquered this vast empire; an empire so large that he, sitting at the centre of it, cannot know all the many parts of it. He canât visit them, he canât see them, and if he goes to one part all the other parts have changed. So he sits there at the centre of his empire and Marco Polo travels around and visits the various cities and comes... (Source)

Bianca Belair@ylc130 I went to the library when I was in the 3rd grade and read Beloved... I remember being so confused and my Mama having to explain it to me... I later read it as an adult and it hit me completely different. GREAT BOOK! (Source)

Farah Jasmine GriffinBeloved was Morrisonâs fifth novel. Itâs a gripping story, inspired by a famous abolitionist case, the true story of a woman who runs away from slavery with her children, but when the slave catchers catch up with her, she kills one of her own and tries to kill the others, rather than returning them to slavery. (Source)

Karl MarlantesBut when OâBrien wrote The Things They Carried he came down to absolute real brass tacks. It was no longer surreal, it was like hereâs a list of what a grunt carries, an infantry soldierâ¦ (Source)

Eugene Gu@realDonaldTrump Tim OâBrien is the author of the book The Things They Carried, which was about the Vietnam War. Must be very triggering for Trump since he dodged the draft multiple times with fraudulent doctorsâ notes for fake bone spurs like a coward. (Source)

Brian KoppelmanIf you have always wanted to read [this author], I think this [Covid-19] period of time is perfect for it. He could have conceived of this whole thing. (Source)

Bernard TanIâm also a Murakami and Vonnegut fan, Kafka on the Shore, The Wind-up Bird Chronicle, Norwegian Wood, Slaughterhouse-Five, etc. Now that I look at the books listed, they seem to carry an existential theme. I guess I like to understand humanity and human behaviour ultimately to better understand myself. I find reading a means to connect with people who may have lived before my time, or in a... (Source)

Sung J. WooHeâs the best-known Japanese writer right now and this book I would consider to be his opus. Itâs a big sprawling book that deals with weighty subjects like the Second World War and Japanâs part in that. There is a horrifying section set when the Japanese had occupied Manchuria and the Chinese are approaching and itâs told from the point of view of a soldier who is told to kill all the animals in... (Source)

Jason Kottke@procload Not super necessary, since you've seen the TV show. This first book is still a great read though...different than the show (tone-wise more than plot-wise). (Source)

Will BrookerWatchmen was originally released in 12 parts, one a month, over a year from 1985 to 1986. There was a film made of it in 2009. And now a controversial prequel series is coming out, done by new writers and artists, which goes back to earlier in the charactersâ stories and which has been disavowed by Alan Moore, who created the original. (Source)

Iulia GhitaI like Milan Kunderaâs books with his philosophical digressions that sometimes remind me of my own dilemmas, with The Unbearable Lightness of Being as my favourite. I find Kunderaâs stories awfully sad, but yet so real, so close to human nature. I admit, Iâm not a fan of happy endings, I prefer thought provoking endings. (Source)

Carlos EireThe title, The Unbearable Lightness of Being, comes from the main characterâs obsession with the fact that all we have is the now, nothing else except the ever-moving now. (Source)

Ryan HolidayIâm amazed how many young people havenât read this book. Truly life-changing. This is the classic of my generation; it is the book that defines our age and ultimately, how to find meaning in it. Itâs a cautionary tale tooâabout being too caught up in revolutionary ideas. (Source)

Van BadhamSUPER EXCITED to receive my copy of âSolved! How Other Countries Have Cracked the Worldâs Biggest Problems and We Can, Tooâ by Andrew Wear. SO GREAT to read a political book thatâs about both pragmatic action *and* hope. Squee! #auspol https://t.co/jIYgr36kZO (Source)

Nassim Nicholas TalebThis is something very hard to find, almost by definition: a literary writer who thinks in abstract terms (the only other such author I've read is Stanislaw Lem). These are philosophical thought experiments in their purest form, yet somehow magically delivered in a playful literary athmosphere. Borges is a mathematical philosopher, first and last. Ignore the "Latin American" categorization and... (Source)

Viktor Mayer-SchÃ¶nbergerBorges asks what happens if we canât forget? Will we be forever tied to an excruciatingly detailed past? Or will we be able to forget parts of it over time and therefore be able to evolve and move on? (Source)

Jeff BezosIf you read The Remains of the Day, which is one of my favorite books, you can't help but come away and think, I just spent 10 hours living an alternate life and I learned something about life and about regret. You can't do that in a blog post. (Source)

Riz KhanAbout missed chances and what the British character does to a personâs emotions. There is this brick wall that they canât crack through and after a while a bit of the grout wears away. (Source)

Sol OrwellQuestion: What books had the biggest impact on you? Perhaps changed the way you see things or dramatically changed your career path. Orwell's Animal Farm and 1984 (though Huxley's Brave New World is a better reflection of today's society). (Source)

The Centre for the Study of Existential RiskThis is the perfect book if you want to read about human extinction but you still need to be âseducedâ into it. (Source)

Pavel TsatsoulineMost people exist between the on and off switch. They are unable to turn on and put out high power, and they are unable to turn off completely and enjoy true rest. To learn how to control your on and off switch, read the book Psych by Dr. Judd Biasiotto. He is one of the most successful power lifters in history, having squatted over 600 pounds at a bodyweight of 132... drug free, at the age of... (Source)

Brian KoppelmanIf you have always wanted to read [this author], I think this [Covid-19] period of time is perfect for it. He could have conceived of this whole thing. (Source)

Bernard TanIâm also a Murakami and Vonnegut fan, Kafka on the Shore, The Wind-up Bird Chronicle, Norwegian Wood, Slaughterhouse-Five, etc. Now that I look at the books listed, they seem to carry an existential theme. I guess I like to understand humanity and human behaviour ultimately to better understand myself. I find reading a means to connect with people who may have lived before my time, or in a... (Source)

John CraigThe only book, or should I say author, that takes priority is Haruki Murakami. He is a Japanese novelist that takes me into the next world. His style is surreal. Check it out. Start with Kafka on the Shore. (Source)

Igor DebaturQuestion: What five books would you recommend to young people interested in your career path & why? Answer: The Glass Bead Game by Herman Hesse Foucault's Pendulum by Umberto Eco The Antichrist by Friedrich Nietzsche The Castle by Franz Kafka 1984 by George Orwell and Brave New World by Aldous Huxley (Source)

Woody AllenIt was such a relief from the other books I was reading at the time, which all had a quality of homework to them. (Source)

Matthew OâBrienItâs one of my favourite books and probably my favourite Las Vegas-related book. Hunter S Thompson came out here in the early 70s to cover the Mint 400 off-road race for Sports Illustrated. He ended up writing a 10,000-word riff on his visit. In 1971, Jann Wenner ultimately published two long sections of it in Rolling Stone. Those two stories were the foundation for Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas. (Source)

Chad HarbachThis is DeLilloâs big, thick novel which ranges over several decades of American history. Itâs a book about waste, about trash, about what society sweeps under the rug. But it begins with a long overture set in perhaps the most famous professional baseball game of all time â âThe Shot Heard Round The World,â the famous home run hit by Bobby Thomson in 1951. Itâs an incredibly virtuosic piece of... (Source)

Stephen LawThis is an entertaining book. Itâs very different. The theme is still pseudoscience. Alan Sokal is a scientist, perhaps best known for the Sokal hoax. He became increasingly irritated by the way in which scientific jargon was being used by postmodern writers in a nonsensical or ridiculous way in their publications, so he decided to expose this by writing a spoof postmodern article called... (Source)

Oprah WinfreyIt's got everything that's grabbing the headlines in America right now. It's about race and class, the economy, culture, immigration and the danger of the us-versus-them mentality. And underneath it all, pumps the heart and soul of family love, the pursuit of happiness, and what home really means. (Source)

James MillerIt is such a powerful story â¦ against an utterly bleak scenario you have the father and the son, and the novel builds up this incredibly emotive relationship. (Source)

Mark BoyleIn my view, The Road is the greatest novel ever written, and McCarthy one of the most important writers of the last hundred years. Its bleakness is interspersed with sentences so beautiful I wept. (Source)

Timothy FerrissRaised in a culture where men are powerful, sexual, and dominant, the Klingon-speaking, D&D-playing chubby boy thinks heâll never find true love or physical affection. Oscar struggles as a young immigrant from the Dominican Republic living with his older sister and mother in Paterson, New Jersey. A fun read with lots of geek culture, great history, and oh, it also won the Pulitzer Prize. (Source)

Cristina RiesenFirst, a word on career paths. In time, I realised that career paths are like one-way streets. Magic happens in unexplored territories. Plus life is how you choose to live every moment, every day. So today, rather than building a career, I prefer to make lateral moves in life, working with great people and being part of ambitious projects impacting the world. There are a few books that got me... (Source)

Mark O'Connellthereâs something culturally Irish, but not uniquely Irish, of using logic against itself â of exposing the absurdity thatâs inherent in logic, if you know what I mean âthat he does incredibly well. (Source)

John KingI have read this once and I keep dipping back into it because it is endlessly fascinating. Roberto BolaÃ±o is a writer who has found a really important way of dealing with the horrors that the 1970s and subsequent decades have inflicted on Latin America. If you look at Borges, GarcÃ­a MÃ¡rquez and Vargas Llosa, in a sense they grew up in times of optimism, of high modernism, with the hope, at least... (Source)

Chibli MallatYes, my interest in Deleuze started when I read his Proust et les Signes in high school in Paris in 1977. He was still relatively unknown outside France. Since then I have pillaged his extraordinary conceptual coinage â I use âThousand Planesâ (my translation of Mille Plateaux) in my Introduction to Middle Eastern Law as a holding concept for 4,000 years of Middle Eastern and Islamic law. It is... (Source)

Anthony JuliusIâm interested in the trials, of course â particularly the trial here, but also the trial in the States â because of what they meant in the context of the 1960s. Just as Iâm interested in what The Satanic Verses meant at the moment of its publication in 1989/90: with the collapse of the Berlin Wall and the end of the Cold War, the extinction of socialism as a project of human liberation, and,... (Source)

Bryan CallenSo here are my three must read books. I've been reading a lot of great books like: Outsmart Your Instincts, The Culture Code, and Antonio Damasioâs The Strange Order, and sometimes when you read a lot of nonfiction itâs very enriching, sometimes you need a novel. I really believe you should take a minute and read something beautiful. Listen, listen to Lolita by Nabokov. But also listen to Blood... (Source)

Brian KoppelmanIf you have always wanted to read [this author], I think this [Covid-19] period of time is perfect for it. He could have conceived of this whole thing. (Source)

Stephen CaveThis story is about a Roman officer who finds the fountain of youth, a river that cleanses men of death, as he puts it. He becomes an immortal and meets the other immortals who have found the river, and the story is about the consequences of this â namely, madness and meaninglessness. Thereâs a great deal of speculation among philosophers and religious types about what it might be like to live... (Source)

Tendai Biti2)Marquez s âLove in the time of choleraâ & â100 yrs of solitude â are two of my top books but one still weeps reading or re- reading Tolstoy s â War & Peace âa book bettered only by â Anna Karenina. Not a fan of these motivational books but that âf#cked â up book is quite funny (Source)

Bryan CallenSo here are my three must read books. I've been reading a lot of great books like: Outsmart Your Instincts, The Culture Code, and Antonio Damasioâs The Strange Order, and sometimes when you read a lot of nonfiction itâs very enriching, sometimes you need a novel. I really believe you should take a minute and read something beautiful. Listen, listen to Lolita by Nabokov. But also listen to Blood... (Source)

Kate FigesItâs partly such a passionate book because of the beauty of the prose, describing love through time and how she found contentment â love, passion and sex all in one. (Source)

Amy ChuaLaura Brown makes the strictest of tiger mothers look wonderful by comparison. She is totally detached and canât get out of her head, so she retreats into books, specifically Mrs. Dalloway. (Source)

William DalrympleOf all the great modern Indian novels, of which there has been a flood, Arundhati Roy is the one I enjoyed most. Itâs got that fabulous quality, in the literal sense. It has a craftsmanship to it, and one of the greatest endings to any novel. There are so few modern novels which end perfectly, with that perfect click into place, the lock clicking shut. But it has that, and itâs a very... (Source)

Amy ChuaHis mother and father died within five weeks of each other, and at 21 he finds himself a single parent in charge of his eight-year-old brother. (Source)
